## Reactive let/var declarations in legacy mode

In legacy mode, top-level variables are automatically reactive. Reassigning or mutating them triggers UI updates.

```svelte
<script>
	let count = 0;
</script>

<button on:click={() => count += 1}>
	clicks: {count}
</button>
```

Reactivity is based on assignments, not mutations. Array methods like `.push()` and `.splice()` won't trigger updatesâ€”you must reassign the variable afterward:

```svelte
<script>
	let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4];

	function addNumber() {
		numbers.push(numbers.length + 1); // doesn't trigger update
		numbers = numbers; // reassignment triggers update
	}
</script>
```

## Reactive let/var in legacy mode

Top-level variables are automatically reactive. Reactivity is assignment-based, so mutations like `.push()` require a reassignment to trigger updates:

```svelte
let numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4];
numbers.push(5); // no update
numbers = numbers; // triggers update
```
Legacy mode makes top-level variables reactive via assignments; mutations alone don't trigger updates without reassignment.
